Dear Tia M. Cobb:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
8/16/2024. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 3 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
2023 Renewal Corrective Action Plan was recorded during this reporting period as
a result of the Renewal inspection completed on 8/18/2023. This CAP contained 7
violations pertaining to criminal and central registry record checks, dated
references, written employee evaluations, First Aid/CPR certification, discharge
plan and documentation of resident legal status. Two were found repeated in this
interim inspection therefore, additional corrective action planning will be needed to
address the repeat violations established.
4

Special Investigation 2024C0000897SI with CAP approval date of 2/20/2024,
violations were found pertaining to improper physical restraint techniques,
documentation of restraints, procedures surrounding incident reports and health
status requirements.
Special Investigation 2024C0000982SI with CAP approval date of 04/08/2024,
violations were found pertaining to staff using degratory language towards a youth
and for inappropriately secluding youth.
The corrective action plans have been monitored throughout this period under
review and they have completed the action steps required. The agency has made
significate improvement to their program by focusing on verbal de-escalation,
increase in direct care supervision, and supervisor mentoring and providing
support to new staff. The facility is in compliance with all corrective action plans.
Financial Overview
There are no financial concerns identified based on a review of the facility’s budget
and the agency financial audit.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
The agency is compliant with PREA.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator Assessment was completed and identified new processes
implemented into staff training such as a shadowing form for new employees that
helps with identifying employee strengths and areas of additional training.
Experienced staff (Coordinators) float the pods and provide support and mentor
direct care staff. Managers and Directors are watching live footage of all the pods
to ensure staff are providing appropriate care and supervision. The facility is
continually assessing methods to improve supporting existing and expanding
recruitment of new staff. The facility has weekly hiring fair’s to ensure they have
sufficient staff. The agency continues to request and receive a variance allowing for
seclusion in certain circumstances.
Staff and Youth Interviews
The staff interviewed reported they enjoy working at the facility and feel they have
the appropriate training and tools to do their job. They further reported feeling
supported by management.
5

The youths interviewed reported their needs are being met, they are participating in
group and individual therapy, they engage in outside activities and art therapy and
are being supervised by staff. Youths expressed no concerns regarding the facility
or staff.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The facility was neat, clean and well organized. The staff offices, pods, classrooms,
kitchen, meal rooms, and control rooms were viewed, and no concerns were noted.
The meal plans were posted in each cafeteria/kitchen area.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
